q: Does Swami narrate any incident surrounding Shivaratri?
a:
In the provided passage, Swami Sarvapriyananda shares an incident involving Swami Shivamayanji, but it does not explicitly mention Shivaratri. However, the narrative does offer insights into the experiences and teachings of the swamis.

According to the passage, Swami Shivamayanji once told a group of young monks, including Swami Sarvapriyananda, about an experience he had with his guru, Swami Gambhirananda. Swami Gambhirananda, at the time a vice president and later president of the Ramakrishna Math and Ramakrishna Mission, was describing the nature of God realization. He explained that the living form of the chosen deity appears in one's heart as a blazing or flaming form (Bengali: Amin jakhoni chok bhoji. Ishta murti. Jaljal kare bhaveshe othe). Swami Gambhirananda further emphasized the importance of realizing Brahman in all beings, indicating a deep understanding and connection with the divine in everything and everyone.

Swami Shivamayanji used this story to teach the young monks about the expectations of people who show respect and reverence to them. He wanted to remind them of the importance of their conduct and the impact they have on others.

While this narrative does not directly mention Shivaratri, it does provide a glimpse into the teachings and values of the swamis, which likely influenced their celebrations and observations of various Hindu festivals, including Shivaratri.
